context: [12] Changes in pulmonary function attenuated with repeated exposures. [13] Potentially serious effects may occur, but it has generally been found that outdoor levels are low; there can be greater danger from some indoor environments such as gas heated homes and poorly ventilated residences inside which fires are lit such as are found in underdeveloped countries. [1] O3 forms in the atmosphere through very complex chemical interactions and equilibria between hundreds of different hydrocarbons and radicals and NO and NO2, all requiring photochemical energy. [2] Daily ambient O3 levels in the United Kingdom rarely exceed 100 ppb, at which concentration significant decrements in lung function (forced vital capacity (FVC); forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1); mean forced expiratory flow between 25 and 75% of FVC (FEF25â€“75); airway resistance (RAW)) have been observed at an exercise intensity equating to a VÌ‡e of 70.0 litres/min. [3] Figure 3 shows monthly statistics for O3 in 1997. [4] As expected, O3 levels were higher in the summer than the winter. [5] In large hot cities such as Los Angeles, a diurnal pattern of O3 concentration is observed, peaking around midday well after the morning rush hour and when solar radiation is at its highest.
